Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: An Exploration of Faculty Expertise and Student Learning in Capstone Experiences

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This CAREER project explores the question, ?What constitutes expert teaching in the capstone environment?? This question examines the ?epistemology of engineering educators,? highlighted by the NSF-funded Engineering Education Research Colloquies as a core research area, in order to more effectively prepare current and future faculty to support student learning. This question will be answered in a four-phase mixed methods study consisting of 1) a national survey of capstone instructors informed by prior literature on both design education and teaching expertise, 2) interviews with selected instructors identified by the national survey, paired with surveys of the interview subjects? students; 3) in-depth case studies of expert instructors identified by the interviews and student surveys; and 4) development, implementation, and assessment of innovative online programs for graduate students and faculty to enhance teaching.
This project builds on the growing body of research in two domains: design education and teacher expertise. Design education researchers have analyzed key design activities, compared practices of novices and experts, explored the role of reflective practice, examined problem definition, proposed instructional materials, and designed learning outcomes and assessments. At the same time, research on teacher expertise has identified practices associated with expert teaching in K-12, including domain knowledge, flexibility in adapting curricula, and effective monitoring of student learning. But researchers and faculty still lack a concrete understanding of teaching expertise in design education. The proposed CAREER project will make substantial contributions to the research in both domains, as well as provide a basis for future studies of design teaching and learning across the curriculum. The PI is experienced in the quantitative and qualitative research methods required for the study, and her prior research on design education provides a strong foundation for the work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcomes and Intellectual Merit: Capstone design courses provide a critical bridge between school and industry by giving students the chance to work in teams on a long-term (usually 2 semesters) real-world project. These courses require faculty to move beyond helping students master content and instead help them develop the skills to think and act like professional engineers on an open-ended project. Instead of lecturing, design faculty mentor students and coach them through real-world engineering work to move them from “student” to “professional engineer.”

 But this teaching is often challenging because it is so different from the more familiar ways of simply delivering content. By concretely defining “good” teaching in this context, with specific practices, this project helps faculty across the country more effectively prepare graduating seniors for industry work. Using surveys, observations, and interviews, we have identified 9 core practices that faculty and industry mentors use to guide students through capstone projects and prepare them to enter the engineering workforce. These practices reflect the important work that mentors do as they interact with novice engineers to help them design and develop the technology of the future.

Although the practices were initially identified through interviews with faculty, interviews with students consistently point to the importance of these mentoring relationships. Students deeply value the relationships they are able to build with mentors that help them not only manage technical project details, but develop their understanding of real-world engineering work as they develop essential professional skills. Using surveys, observations, and interviews with students, we have several identified critical learning outcomes associated with these mentoring relationships, including increased professionalism and confidence in themselves as engineers, better understanding of industry practices, more effective teamwork and project management, and improved self-directed learning. These outcomes are directly linked to the expectations and needs of contemporary workplaces, and reinforce the importance of helping faculty learn these mentoring practices. Expert design educators serve as important role models for what it means to “be” an engineer, and students demonstrate deep learning from these role models.

Broader Impact and Benefits of the Project: To put these findings into practice, the research team has developed and implemented training materials, including workshops and web resources, that can be used by capstone course coordinators around the country to train and support faculty and industry mentors who work with students. At the same time, as more faculty shift away from traditional lectures and incorporate project-based learning into their courses, these mentoring practices are becoming increasingly important for faculty at all levels, and the materials have been designed to be readily adaptable to different types of courses. By better preparing faculty to mentor and coach engineering design teams, we can help them better prepare graduating engineers to enter the workforce with the skills and attitudes that are essential for critical technology development.
